question: Which aileron positions should a pilot generally use when taxiing in strong quartering headwinds?
choices: Ailerons neutral.
Aileron down on the side from which the wind is blowing.
Aileron up on the side from which the wind is blowing.

question: What action is required when two aircraft of the same category converge, but not head-on?
choices: Each aircraft shall give way to the right.
The aircraft on the left shall give way.
The faster aircraft shall give way.

question: What period of time must a person be hospitalized before an injury may be defined by the NTSB as a 'serious injury'?
choices: 72 hours; commencing within 10 days after date of the injury.
48 hours; commencing within 7 days after date of the injury.
10 days, with no other extenuating circumstances.

question: Under which condition will pressure altitude be equal to true altitude?
choices: When standard atmospheric conditions exist.
When indicated altitude is equal to the pressure altitude.
When the atmospheric pressure is 29.92 inches Hg.

question: What is the difference between a normal landing and a crosswind landing?
choices: Aileron up on the upwind wing
Aileron up on the downwind wing
Aileron down on the upwind wing

question: When should a pilot contact the tower of a Class C airport when departing from a satellite airport underlying the Class C?
choices: After departure, when practical.
On the ground before departure.
You should remain on the CTAF for the departure airport.

question: Which is true with respect to a high - or low-pressure system?
choices: A low-pressure area or trough is an area of descending air.
A high-pressure area or ridge is an area of rising air.
A high-pressure area or ridge is an area of descending air.

question: What input is required to maintain altitude during steep turns?
choices: Back pressure on the yoke.
Aileron in the opposite direction of the turn.
Increase power.

question: How should the flight controls be held while taxiing a tricycle-gear equipped airplane into a left quartering headwind?
choices: Left aileron up, elevator neutral.
Left aileron down, elevator neutral.
Left aileron up, elevator down.

question: Prior to takeoff, the altimeter should be set to which altitude or altimeter setting?
choices: The current local altimeter setting, if available, or the departure airport elevation.
The corrected pressure altitude for the departure airport.
The corrected density altitude of the departure airport.

question: On landing, your tire blows and the wheel is dented. What action is required to comply with NTSB Part 830?
choices: A report must be filed with the nearest FAA field office within 7 days.
No notification or report is required.
An immediate notification must be filed by the operator of the aircraft with the nearest NTSB field office.

question: You must notify the NTSB immediately if the following occurs:
choices: The inability of any required flight crewmember to perform normal flight duties as a result of injury or illness.
In-flight roll upset greater than 90° of bank
Flight through a Prohibited Area without an ATC clearance

question: After landing at a tower-controlled airport, when should the pilot contact ground control?
choices: Prior to turning off the runway.
After reaching a taxiway that leads directly to the parking area.
When advised by the tower to do so.

question: What is an important airspeed limitation that is not color coded on airspeed indicators?
choices: Never-exceed speed.
Maximum structural cruising speed.
Maneuvering speed.

question: When must batteries in an emergency locator transmitter (ELT) be replaced or recharged, if rechargeable?
choices: When the ELT can no longer be heard over the airplane's communication radio receiver.
After any inadvertent activation of the ELT.
When the ELT has been in use for more than 1 cumulative hour.

question: An abnormally high engine oil temperature indication may be caused by
choices: the oil level being too low.
operating with an excessively rich mixture.
operating with a too high viscosity oil.

question: Cold air generally contains:
choices: More water vapor than cold air.
More suspended water particles.
Less water vapor than warm air.

question: One in-flight condition necessary for structural icing to form is
choices: stratiform clouds.
small temperature/dewpoint spread.
visible moisture.

question: How can you determine the stability of an air mass?
choices: Winds aloft forecast.
Observe the cloud formations and type of precipitation.
Height of the cloud bases.

question: How should the ailerons be positioned when landing in a crosswind?
choices: Up aileron into the wind
Neutral ailerons
Down aileron into the wind

question: Steady precipitation preceding a front is an indication of
choices: stratiform clouds with moderate turbulence.
cumuliform clouds with little or no turbulence.
stratiform clouds with little or no turbulence.

question: Under what condition will true altitude be lower than indicated altitude?
choices: When density altitude is higher than indicated altitude.
In colder than standard air temperature.
In warmer than standard air temperature.

question: Under what condition is indicated altitude the same as true altitude?
choices: If the altimeter has no mechanical error.
When at sea level under standard conditions.
When at 18,000 feet MSL with the altimeter set at 29.92.

question: What is required for thermals to form?
choices: High humidity
Thunderstorms
Solar heating

question: When squawking the VFR code (1200) on your transponder, what is the minimum mode the transponder must be in?
choices: Mode C.
Mode F.
Mode A.

question: When the course deviation indicator (CDI) needle is centered during an omnireceiver check using a VOR test signal (VOT), the omnibearing selector (OBS) and the TO/FROM indicator should read
choices: 0° TO or 180° FROM, regardless of the pilot's position from the VOT.
180° FROM, only if the pilot is due north of the VOT.
0° FROM or 180° TO, regardless of the pilot's position from the VOT.

question: SIGMETs are issued as a warning of weather conditions hazardous to which aircraft?
choices: Large aircraft only.
All aircraft.
Small aircraft only.

question: While operating under BasicMed as pilot in command, the aircraft:
choices: Must be limited to 5 seats and not certified for more than 6,000 lbs.
Must be limited to 12 seats and not certified for more than 12,500 lbs.
Must be limited to 7 seats and not certified for more than 12,500 lbs.

question: The pitot system provides impact pressure for which instrument?
choices: Airspeed indicator.
Altimeter.
Vertical-speed indicator.

question: While inbound to a nontowered airport without automated weather services, you listen to the CTAF and hear no other aircraft on the frequency. How can you determine the winds and active runway?
choices: Call the nearest ATC approach or Center facility.
Call on the CTAF and request an Airport Advisory.
Fly a straight-in final approach and scan for other traffic.

question: One of the most easily recognized discontinuities across a front is
choices: a change in temperature.
an increase in relative humidity.
an increase in cloud coverage.

question: What does a steady red light signal from an ATC control tower mean when in flight?
choices: Exercise extreme caution
Airport unsafe, do not land
Give way and continue circling

question: How many GPS satellites are required to provide a three-dimensional position?
(Refer to Figure 68.) On the wind triangle, the line from point C to B represents:
choices: True heading and groundspeed.
Airspeed and heading.
Groundspeed and true course.

question: (Refer to Figure 68.) On the wind triangle, the line from point C to A represents:
choices: Wind direction and velocity.
True heading and groundspeed.
True course and groundspeed.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, a magnetic compass will normally indicate initially a turn toward the east if
choices: an aircraft is accelerated while on a north heading.
a left turn is entered from a north heading.
an aircraft is decelerated while on a south heading.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, a magnetic compass will normally indicate initially a turn toward the west if
choices: a left turn is entered from a north heading.
an aircraft is accelerated while on a north heading.
a right turn is entered from a north heading.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, a magnetic compass will normally indicate initially a turn toward the north if
choices: an aircraft is decelerated while on an east or west heading.
a left turn is entered from a west heading.
an aircraft is accelerated while on an east or west heading.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, the magnetic compass will normally indicate a turn toward the south when
choices: a left turn is entered from an east heading.
a right turn is entered from a west heading.
the aircraft is decelerated while on a west heading.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, a magnetic compass will normally indicate initially a turn toward the south if
choices: a left turn is entered from an east heading.
a right turn is entered from a west heading.
the aircraft is decelerated while on a west heading.

question: The movement of the air affects the speed at which aircraft move:
choices: In a turn.
Over the Earth's surface.
Through the air.

question: Inbound to an airport with no tower, FSS, or UNICOM in operation, a pilot should self-announce on MULTICOM frequency
With certain exceptions, safety belts are required to be secured about passengers during
choices: all flight conditions.
flight in turbulent air.
taxi, takeoffs, and landings.

question: (Refer to Figure 26, area 1.) What might you expect when flying in an MOA such as Devils Lake.
choices: Unusual, often invisible, hazards to aircraft such as artillery firing, aerial gunnery, or guided missiles.
High volume of pilot training or an unusual type of aerial activity.
Air combat tactics, air intercepts, aerobatics, formation training, and low−altitude tactics.

question: If a person is convicted of flying an airplane while intoxicated, he or she might expect:
choices: Denial of an application for an FAA certificate or rating.
To write a report to the FAA Civil Aviation Security Division (AMC-700) not later than 60 day after the conviction.
To write a notification of the conviction to the FAA Civil Aeromedical Institute.

question: No person may attempt to act as a crewmember of a civil aircraft with
choices: .008 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.
.004 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.
.04 percent by weight or more alcohol in the blood.

question: Where should you perform the pre-takeoff checks at the airport?
choices: Apron area after starting the engine.
Run-up area near the takeoff end of the runway.
On a taxiway along the way to the runway.

question: How is the wing twisted on most training airplanes to increase controllability at low speeds?
choices: The wing is twisted to a higher AOA at the wing tip.
The wing is twisted to a lower AOA at the wing root.
The wing is twisted to a higher AOA at the wing root.

question: What is/are the aircraft inspection requirement(s) when receiving dual flight instruction in your own airplane?
choices: 100-hour inspection
Annual inspection
Annual inspection and a 100-hour inspection

question: Automatic Terminal Information Service (ATIS) is the continuous broadcast of recorded information concerning
choices: pilots of radar-identified aircraft whose aircraft is in dangerous proximity to terrain or to an obstruction.
noncontrol information in selected high-activity terminal areas.
nonessential information to reduce frequency congestion.

question: When are non-rechargeable batteries of an emergency locator transmitter (ELT) required to be replaced?
choices: At the time of each 100-hour or annual inspection.
Every 24 months.
When 50 percent of their useful life expires.

question: While operating under BasicMed, the pilot in command must have visited their primary care physician within the preceding:
choices: 48 months.
12 months.
24 months.

question: The most accurate part of a forecast occurs:
choices: At the end of the forecast period.
Some hours after the forecast period.
At the beginning of the forecast period.

question: In the Northern Hemisphere, if an aircraft is accelerated or decelerated, the magnetic compass will normally indicate
choices: correctly when on a north or south heading.
a turn toward the south.
a turn momentarily.

question: If an aircraft is equipped with a fixed-pitch propeller and a float-type carburetor, the first indication of carburetor ice would most likely be
choices: engine roughness.
a drop in oil temperature and cylinder head temperature.
loss of RPM.

question: The operator of an aircraft that has been involved in an accident is required to file an NTSB accident report within how many days?
What should be the indication on the magnetic compass as you roll into a standard rate turn to the right from a south heading in the Northern Hemisphere?
choices: The compass will remain on south for a short time, then gradually catch up to the magnetic heading of the airplane.
The compass will indicate a turn to the right, but at a faster rate than is actually occurring.
The compass will initially indicate a turn to the left.

question: (Refer to figure 9, area B.) How should the flight controls be held while taxiing a tailwheel airplane into a right quartering headwind?
choices: Right aileron up, elevator up.
Right aileron down, elevator neutral.
Right aileron up, elevator down.

question: Which records or documents shall the owner or operator of an aircraft keep to show compliance with an applicable Airworthiness Directive?
choices: Airworthiness Certificate and Pilot's Operating Handbook.
Airworthiness and Registration Certificates.
Aircraft maintenance records.

question: What type of turbulence would a pilot expect in a Mammatus cloud?
choices: Moderate
Severe
Light

question: Which conditions result in the formation of frost?
choices: The temperature of the surrounding air is at or below freezing when small drops of moisture fall on the collecting surface.
The temperature of the collecting surface is at or below the dewpoint of the adjacent air and the dewpoint is below freezing.
The temperature of the collecting surface is at or below freezing when small droplets of moisture fall on the surface.

question: The operator of an aircraft that has been involved in an incident is required to submit a report to the nearest field office of the NTSB
choices: when requested.
within 10 days.
within 7 days.

question: If a recreational or private pilot had a flight review on August 8, this year, when is the next flight review required?
choices: August 8, next year.
August 31, 1 year later.
August 31, 2 years later.

question: The purpose of the fuel tank vent system is to:
choices: allow air to enter as fuel is consumed to maintain atmospheric pressure inside the tank.
allow for the proper air to fuel ratio when flying at higher altitudes.
increase pressure in the tank to move fuel to the engine intake.

question: The 'yellow demarcation bar' marking indicates
choices: runway with a displaced threshold that precedes the runway.
a hold line from a taxiway to a runway.
the beginning of available runway for landing on the approach side.

question: The correct method of stating 10,500 feet MSL to ATC is
choices: 'ONE ZERO THOUSAND, FIVE HUNDRED.'
'TEN THOUSAND, FIVE HUNDRED FEET.'
'TEN POINT FIVE.'

question: You want your wind ground track and ____________to be the same.
choices: Heading.
Drift angle.
Course.

question: When does P-factor cause the airplane to yaw to the left?
choices: When at high airspeeds.
When at high angles of attack.
When at low angles of attack.

question: Except when necessary for takeoff or landing, what is the minimum safe altitude required for a pilot to operate an aircraft over other than a congested area?
choices: An altitude of 500 feet AGL, except over open water or a sparsely populated area, which requires 500 feet from any person, vessel, vehicle, or structure.
An altitude of 500 feet above the highest obstacle within a horizontal radius of 1,000 feet.
An altitude allowing, if a power unit fails, an emergency landing without undue hazard to persons or property on the surface.

question: Which incident requires an immediate notification to the nearest NTSB field office?
choices: A forced landing due to engine failure.
Flight control system malfunction or failure.
Landing gear damage, due to a hard landing.

question: Safety belts are required to be properly secured about which persons in an aircraft and when?
choices: Passengers, during taxi, takeoffs, and landings only.
Pilots only, during takeoffs and landings.
Each person on board the aircraft during the entire flight.

question: What is the purpose of the taxiway directional sign?
choices: Indicates designation and direction of exit taxiway from runway.
Indicates direction to take-off runway.
Indicates designation and direction of taxiway leading out of an intersection.

question: When the term 'light and variable' is used in reference to a Winds Aloft Forecast, the coded group and windspeed is
choices: 9999 and less than 10 knots.
9900 and less than 5 knots.
0000 and less than 7 knots.

question: There is no acceleration/deceleration error on a heading of:
choices: East or west.
240 degrees or 60 degrees.
North or south.
